1283 (first regulated) | preceded_by = [[Cort Comtal]], [[Peace and Truce of God|Peace and Truce Assemblies]] | succeeded_by = [[Courts of Castile]] | disbanded = 1714 | leader1_type = [[King of Aragon|King of Aragon and Count of Barcelona]] | leader1 = [[List of Aragonese monarchs]] | election1 = | members = {{lang|ca|Síndics}} (''{{lang|ca|Braç Reial}}''), Nobles (''{{lang|ca|Braç Militar}}''), Clerics (''{{lang|ca|Braç Eclesiàstic}}'') | house1 = | house2 = | house3 = | session_room = Casa generalitat web.jpg | session_res = 270px | meeting_place = Itinerant, different places of Catalonia. The {{lang|ca|[[Palau de la Generalitat]]}} was the place where the last Courts (1705-1706) were met | footnotes = ---- See also:
[[Parliament of Catalonia]] }} The '''Catalan Courts''' or '''General Court of Catalonia''' ({{lang-ca|'''Corts Catalanes'''}} or '''''{{lang|ca|Cort General de Catalunya}}'''''){{Cite book |author=Désirée Kleiner-Liebau |title=Migration and the Construction of National Identity in Spain |publisher=Iberoamericana Editorial |year=2009 |url= https://books.google.es/books?id=2-DG72I8MTwC&pg=PA68&dq=%22corts+reials+catalanes%22&hl=es&sa=X&ei=DxrbUP3HO-fX0QXjqIC4CA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22corts%20reials%20catalanes%22&f=false |page= 68}} was the policymaking and [[parliament]]ary body of the [[Principality of Catalonia]] from the 13th to the 18th century. The courts were made up of three arms or estates: the ''military estate'' which included representatives from the nobility, the ''ecclesiastical estate'' which saw representatives from the religious hierarchy and the ''royal'' estate which had representatives from the municipalities.{{Cite web |url=http://www.erepresentative.org/catalonian.htm |title=Catalonian Parliament - The "Corts generals" or Parliament of Catalonia |publisher=eRepresentative |accessdate=21 January 2013}} The courts were summoned by the king who opened with a royal proclamation while the arms were in charge of legislating, always with the support of the sovereign. If the laws that were approved came from the king they received the name of "[[Catalan constitutions|Constitutions]]", if they came from the Estates, "Court Chapters". If the king passed a law unilaterally it was called "Acts of Courts" and required ratification by the courts. It is comparable to similar institutions across [[Europe]], such as the [[Parliament of England]] and the [[Diets]] ({{lang-de|Landtage}}) of the [[Germany|German]] "[[List of historic states of Germany|lands]]". The General Courts of the [[Crown of Aragon]] were the simultaneous meeting of the [[Cortes of Aragon|Courts of Aragon]], Valencian Courts and the Courts of [[Catalonia]]. The [[Kingdom of Majorca]] did not convene Courts and thus sent their representatives to the Courts of the Principality. As the courts could not be held outside of [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]] nor the Principality, they were frequently held in [[Monzón]] or in [[Fraga (Huesca)|Fraga]], Aragonese towns which lay equidistant between [[Zaragoza]] and [[Barcelona]]. Unlike the Courts of Castile of the time which functioned only as an advisory body to which the king granted privileges and exemptions, the Catalan Courts was a regulatory body, as their decisions had the force of law, in the sense that the king could not unilaterally revoke them. ==History== ===Origins=== [[File:Fernando II entre dos escudos del Señal Real de Aragón.jpg|left|thumb|[[Ferdinand II of Aragon]] on his throne flanked by two shields with the emblem of the royal signet. Frontis of a 1495 edition of the Catalan Constitutions.{{Cite web|author=Guillermo Fatás y Guillermo Redondo |url=http://www.derechoaragones.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?posicion=106&path=1269&forma=&presentacion=pagina |title=Blasón de Aragón: el escudo y la bandera |location=Zaragoza |publisher=Diputación General de Aragón |year=1995 |pages=101–102 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131092523/http://www.derechoaragones.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?posicion=106&path=1269&forma=&presentacion=pagina |archivedate=2012-01-31 |df= }}]] The origin of the Catalan Courts is located in the Cort Comtal (circa 1000) and in the meetings of the ''[[Peace and Truce of God|Peace and Truce]]'' that from 1021 met to discuss and agree on the termination of wars and violence. The first Catalan Courts date from 1192, the year in which the townspeople participated for the first time in the meeting of the ''Peace and Truce''. Those of 1214 were convened by the papal legate, Cardinal Pietro di Benevento in the Castell de la Suda, in [[Lleida]] and responded to the need to fix the confusing situation in the country after the death of King Peter of Aragon at the Battle of Muret and the beginning of the reign of his son James I who was only six years old. The new king of Aragon took his oath before prelates and magnates of the royal curia, representatives of cities and villages. At the time of [[James I of Aragon|James I]] (1208-1276), they met summoned by the king as representative of the social classes of the time. ===Regulated Courts=== Under the reign of [[Peter III of Aragon|Peter the Great]] (1276-1285), the Catalan courts took institutional form. ==== Court of 1283 ==== In the courts held in Barcelona in 1283, the king was forced to hold a General Court once a year, with representative participation of the time, to discuss the good of the state and land reform. The king himself stated: ''«...si nós i els successors nostres volem fer alguna constitució o estatut a Catalunya, els sotmetrem a l'aprovació i consentiment dels Prelats, dels Barons, dels Cavallers i dels Ciutadans...»''.{{Cite web |url=http://usuarios.multimania.es/maarian/Catalunya/historiacataluna/las_cortes_catalanas_.htm |title=Las Cortes Catalanas y la primera Generalidad medieval (s. XIII-XIV) |accessdate=21 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019003946/http://usuarios.multimania.es/Maarian/Catalunya/historiacataluna/las_cortes_catalanas_.htm |archivedate=19 October 2010 |df= }} (Translation from [[Catalan language|Catalan]]: "if we and our successors want to make a constitution or statute in Catalonia, we will submit them to the approval and consent of the prelates, barons, knights and citizens ..."). ==== Court of 1289 ==== [[File:Escudo de la Generalitat de Catalunya.jpg|thumb|Signet of the Delegation of the Generality of the [[Principality of Catalonia]] in the late fifteenth century representing its patron bearing the shield of the Cross of St. George which were the arms of the Generalitat of Catalonia. On the caption: S(igillum): CORTIUM: ET: PARLAMENTORUM: GENERALIUM: PRINCIPATUS: CATHALONIE (''Seal of the Courts and the Parliament of the Principality of Catalonia'') {{Cite book |author=Alberto Montaner Frutos |title= El señal del rey de Aragón: Historia y significado (The symbol of the king of Aragon: History and meaning) |location=Zaragoza |publisher= Fernando el Católico Institución |year=1995 |at=p. 156 fig. 68 |isbn=84-7820-283-8 |language=Spanish}}]] In the courts held in Monzón in 1289, Delegation of the General Court was appointed as a permanent council to collect the "service" or tribute that the arms granted to the king at his request. Later, this would give rise to the Generalitat of Catalonia, in the fourteenth century. Its regulation was also used to create in the fifteenth century the Valencian Generalitat. ==== Court of 1358 ==== In the Parliament of 1358-1359, held in Barcelona, [[Vilafranca del Penedès]] and [[Cervera, Lleida|Cervera]] under King Peter IV, [[Crown of Castile|Castile]] invaded Aragon and Valencia. This caused a series of armed conflicts that resulted in considerable expenses to the [[Crown of Aragon]]. This circumstance prompted the courts to appoint twelve deputies with executive powers in taxation and some "oïdors de comptes" who controlled the administration, under the authority of [[Berenguer de Cruïlles]], bishop of [[Girona]], who is regarded as the first [[President of the Generalitat of Catalonia|President]] of the [[Generalitat de Catalunya|Generalitat]].{{cite book|author=Adam J. Kosto |title=Making Agreements in Medieval Catalonia: Power, Order, and the Written Word, 1000-1200 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4S0ign7GGOkC&pg=PA254 |accessdate=21 January 2013|date=3 May 2001 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-79239-4}} ===Early modern history=== In 1519, the Courts met in Barcelona to recognize the first unified monarch of all the crowns of Castile and Aragon, -[[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles I]], and to discuss the granting of financial assistance to the Cort reial (Royal court). It was during the king's stay in Barcelona that he got the news that Charles had been elected emperor of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] under the name of Charles V.{{Cite book |author=Fernández Álvarez, Manuel |title=Carlos V, el César y el hombre |publisher=Círculo de Lectores |location=Barcelona |year=2001 |pages=102–113}} During the period of the [[Habsburg Spain|Austrians]], the Courts were summoned less and less because of a supposed brake from the absolute power of the king. Therefore, the Generalitat, as the body responsible for ensuring compliance with the [[Catalan constitutions|constitutions of Catalonia]], gained in strength and prominence. The last General Courts were held in Barcelona in 1705-1706, which, according to historian Joaquim Albareda, represented an important advance in the guarantee of individual, [[civil and political rights]] (for example, establishing the [[secrecy of correspondence]]),{{Cite book |author=Albareda Salvadó, Joaquim |title=La Guerra de Sucesión de España (1700-1714) |year=2010 |pages=182–183 }} while at the same time they consolidated many of the constitutional reforms of the last previous Courts (1701-1702) such as the [[Court of Contraventions]] (Catalan: ''Tribunal de Contrafaccions''), created in order to ensure the application of the constitutions and solve and prosecute any act (included the ones done by the king or his officers) contrary to the Catalan legislation. This institution disappeared, like the other institutions and the majority of legislation of Catalonia, after the end of the [[War of Spanish Succession|War of Succession]] in 1714, by the [[Nueva Planta decrees]] created by the new Spanish king, [[Philip V of Spain|Philip V]]. The current [[Parliament of Catalonia]], legislative body of [[Generalitat de Catalunya|Catalan autonomous government]], is considered the historical successor of this Courts. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite book |last = Fernández Álvarez |first = Manuel |title = Carlos V, el César y el hombre |year = 2001 |publisher = Círculo de Lectores |location = Barcelona |isbn = 84-226-8919-7 |language=Spanish}} ==See also== *[[Parliament of Catalonia]] *[[Cortes Generales]] *[[Generalitat of Catalonia]] [[Category:Parliament of Catalonia]] [[Category:Politics of Catalonia]] [[Category:Catalan law]] [[Category:Historical legislatures]] [[Category:History of Catalonia]] [[Category:Principality of Catalonia]]

[[United Kingdom]] |type = Christian lobby group |leader_title = National Director |leader_name = Stephen Green |key_people = |website = {{URL|http://www.christianvoice.org.uk}} }} '''Christian Voice''' (CV) is a [[Christian]] [[advocacy group]] based in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4640588.stm|title=Springer tour faces new protests|first=Ian|last=Youngs|date=26 January 2006|work=[[BBC]]}} Its stated objective is "to uphold Christianity as the Faith of the United Kingdom, to be a voice for [[Christian values|Biblical values]] in law and public policy, and to defend and support traditional family life."{{cite web |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about4.html |title=Membership of Christian Voice |accessdate=2010-10-06 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719220743/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about4.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} See also [http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about.html About Us] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719220908/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about.html |date=19 July 2011 }} on Christian Voice website: "We attempt, with God's grace, to analyse current events in the light of scripture, proclaim God's word to those in public life and provide the information Christians need in order to pray with the mind of God and witness in these dark days." Retrieved 3 February 2012. It is independent of religious, denominational, or political parties. CV is led by Stephen Green, with [[Baron Ashbourne|Lord Ashbourne]] as its patron.{{cite web |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about6.html |title=Time to repent for Britain in sin |accessdate=2010-10-06 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719220758/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/about6.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}. Christian Voice website. Green is the group's spokesperson, producing scores of press releases from 2005 to 2010. According to Green, Christian Voice had in excess of 600 members in 2005. The group has been criticised for its positions. David Peel, leader of the [[United Reformed Church]] called Christian Voice "a disgrace"{{cite news | first=Stephen | last=Tomkins | title=A voice in the wilderness | date=28 February 2005 | publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4303965.stm | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language=}} and described their "claim to represent Christians" in the UK as "absurd".{{cite news | first= | last= | title=BBC faces question time over Christian Voice | date=29 September 2005 | publisher=[[Ekklesia (think tank)|Ekklesia]] website | url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/content/news_syndication/article_050929green.shtml | work= | pages= | accessdate=2007-09-11 | language=}} ==Leadership== [[File:Stephen Green.jpg|thumb|260px|right|Stephen Green]] The leader, and sole staff member, of Christian Voice is Stephen Green{{cite web|title=About us - Christian Voice|url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/index.php/about-us/|website=Christian Voice|accessdate=25 July 2017}}, a former Chairman of the Conservative Family Campaign, who attends an [[Assemblies of God in the United Kingdom|Assemblies of God]] Church. In the early 1990s, Green was a prominent campaigner against [[homosexuality]] through the Conservative Family Campaign, and wrote a book called ''The Sexual Dead-End''. In January 2011, Green's former wife, Caroline Green, accused him of repeatedly physically assaulting her and their children, including one incident where he allegedly beat her with a weapon until she bled, and another in which their son allegedly required hospital treatment after having been beaten with a piece of wood. The couple subsequently divorced.{{cite news | first= Frances | last= Hardy | title='In public he rails against immorality as the voice of Christian Britain but in private he is a wife beater, says his former partner' | date=28 January 2011 | publisher=The Daily Mail | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1351585/Stephen-Green-rails-immorality-voice-Christian-Britan-private-wife-beater-says-partner.html#comments | work= | pages= | accessdate=2011-01-29 | language=}} Stating that the article was "highly defamatory" and calling it a "catalogue of smears and distortions stitched together," Green denied some of the allegations.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} ==Positions== Christian Voice has called for [[British law]] to be based on the [[Bible]]. It opposes [[abortion]],{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Radical Christians to target abortion clinics | date=26 February 2005 | publisher=''[[The Times]]'' | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-1501029,00.html | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language= | location=London | first1=Laura | last1=Peek | first2=James | last2=Doran}} [[homosexuality]],{{cite news |first = Terry |last = Kirby |title = Christian Voice director escapes prosecution over anti-gay literature |date = 29 September 2006 |publisher = ''[[The Independent]]'' |url = http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article1771850.ece |work = |pages = |accessdate = 2008-10-02 |language = |location = London |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071221172303/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article1771850.ece |archivedate = 21 December 2007 |df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Co-op bank bars Christian group | date=24 June 2005 | publisher=''BBC News'' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4617849.stm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language=}} [[no-fault divorce]]{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Press release: Blair 'divorced from reality' |date=2 September 2005 |publisher=Christian Voice website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press008.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811111207/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press008.html |archivedate=11 August 2007 }} and compulsory [[sex education]].{{cite news|first=Stephen |last=Green |title=Infertility will rise with compulsory sex education |date=November 2003 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press111.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2010-10-07 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719220805/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press111.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 }}: "Government and the teen sex industry are betraying young people in this country. They should get prepared for a new rise in teenage pregnancies and infertility as a result of today's decision. As for individual young people, the message is stark in today's climate, where 10% have had STIs which lead to infertility and chronic conditions. If you want to have children, and if you don't want an unpleasant wedding present, stay a virgin, and marry a virgin." Additionally it supports the [[death penalty]]{{cite news|first=Stephen |last=Green |title=The woman in adultery |date=November 2003 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Articles/Adultery.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125161352/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Articles/Adultery.html |archivedate=25 January 2007 }} and does not recognise the concept of [[marital rape]].{{cite web |url= http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/index.php/britain-in-sin-2/ |title= Britain in Sin |quote= [The Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994] also introduced an offence of "marital rape," drafted by the Law Commission, unknown in the Law of God, and in conflict with the marriage service of the Book of Common Prayer, where the promises given by a man and woman to each other establish a binding consent to sexual intercourse }} The group has also published a paper [[Criticism of Islam#Truthfulness of Islam and Islamic scriptures|attacking Islam as untrue]], and the portrayal of it as a religion of peace as false.{{cite news|first= |last= |title=What is Islam? |date= |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/islam.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516055308/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/islam.html |archivedate=16 May 2008 }}: "Politicians, the police and Islamic leaders have portrayed it as a religion of peace in which terrorism is an aberration. Multi-faith diehards insist that it is one of many paths to salvation, or that the Allah of Islam and the God of Christianity are one and the same. Is any of this true? Part of the Christian Voice response has been to publish a briefing paper entitled 'Understanding Islam,'...". ===Homosexuality=== Green has expressed support for the [[Uganda Anti-Homosexuality Bill]] (2009) and its associated penalty of death, stating "The Bible calls for the ultimate penalty for sodomy... A Parliamentarian in Uganda is trying to protect his nation's children. The House of Commons of the United Kingdom is trying to corrupt ours."{{cite web|last=Writer |first=Staff |url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2009/12/21/christian-leader-supports-death-penalty-for-gays/ |title=Christian leader supports death penalty for gays |publisher=PinkNews.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06}} ===Abortion=== According to the group, abortion is the killing of human beings comparable to [[The Holocaust]].{{cite web|url=http://www.repentuk.com/abortion.html|title=Abortion: Our Own Holocaust|publisher=Christian Voice|accessdate=2011-12-06}} ===Laws on marital rape=== The group wants to overturn the law on [[marital rape]], stating that the promises given by a man and woman to each other during the marriage service in the [[Book of Common Prayer]] establish a binding consent to sexual intercourse.{{cite web|title=Britain in sin|url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/index.php/britain-in-sin-2/|publisher=Christian Voice|accessdate=27 March 2014}} ==Protests and campaigns== ===Homosexuality=== The group has been involved in campaigns against the [[Gay Police Association]] (GPA). Christian Voice is opposed to police officers participating in [[gay pride]] marches, and in 2003 wrote to the [[Chief Constable]] of each force which it alleged allowed its officers to march in uniform at Pride events. The organisation published the replies on its website and, in the accompanying 16-page document ''Homosexuality and the Police'', described homosexuality as "characterised by disease, degradation, death and denial" and Gay Pride as "intimidating".{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Homosexuality and the police |year=2003 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/police.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516054931/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/police.html |archivedate=16 May 2008 }} On 2 September 2006, Green was arrested while handing out pamphlets urging homosexuals to "turn from their sins" at the Cardiff Mardi Gras. The police considered the leaflets hateful. The [[Crown Prosecution Service]] decided to withdraw their prosecution of Green on the grounds of insufficient evidence; the police stated that this did not "challenge the legality" of his arrest. Green's solicitor indicated he would seek damages in civil court for "abuse of police powers."{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Anti-gay leaflets charge dropped | date=28 September 2006 | publisher=''BBC News'' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/5388626.stm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language=}} ===Blasphemy=== Christian Voice was behind much{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} of the controversy in the UK surrounding ''[[Jerry Springer: The Opera]]'' and a transmission of a performance by the [[BBC]] in 2005.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article518144.ece Evangelical militants go on tour - to stop Springer bandwagon], [[The Times]], 24 February 2005 {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The group stated that the production was [[Blasphemy|blasphemous]] in its depiction of [[Jesus]], [[Mary, the Mother of Jesus|Mary]] and [[God]] as guests on the [[Jerry Springer Show]]. Green said of the production, {{quote|Jerry Springer the Opera portrayed Jesus Christ as a nappy-wearing sexual deviant, who said he was 'a little bit gay'. It called Mary a rape victim, said the birth of Jesus was because 'the condom split', ridiculed His wounds on the cross and the sacrament of Holy Communion, had God as an ineffectual old man who needed guidance from Jerry Springer and finished up with Springer as a counterfeit saviour of mankind who told Jesus to "Grow up for Christ's sake and put some f***ing clothes on."{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Press release: Christian Voice director faces bankruptcy |date=26 June 2008 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press090.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828082108/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press090.html |archivedate=28 August 2008 }}}} The group maintained a presence outside the Cambridge Theatre in [[London]] where it ran. It then mounted protests outside every theatre on the 2006 run of the show, attributing the financial disaster of the tour to divine intervention rather than its own actions. In 2009, it mounted protests outside the [[St Andrews University]] production.{{cite web|author=Monday 20 April 2009 |url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/news/display.var.2503033.0.Christian_activists_target_Springer_in_St_Andrews.php |title=Christian activists target Springer in St Andrews | Herald Scotland |publisher=Theherald.co.uk |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423031017/http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/news/display.var.2503033.0.Christian_activists_target_Springer_in_St_Andrews.php |archivedate=23 April 2009 }} Christian Voice started a campaign for people to complain to the [[BBC]] and published the home addresses and telephone numbers of two BBC executives on their web site, [[Jana Bennett]] (Director of Television) and [[Roly Keating]] (Controller of [[BBC Two]]). Keating subsequently received death threats.{{cite news | first= | last= | title=BBC boss in hiding | date=9 January 2005 | publisher=''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=333419&in_page_id=1770 | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language= | location=London | first1=Andrew | last1=Wilks | first2=Amanda | last2=Perthen}} On 8 January 2007, submissions were made on behalf of Stephen Green at [[Horseferry Road]] Magistrates Court to pursue private prosecutions for blasphemy against the [[Director General of the BBC]] [[Mark Thompson (television executive)|Mark Thompson]] and the show's producer, Jonathan Thoday.{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Press release: Jerry Springer The Opera – blasphemy case begins |date=8 January 2007 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press024.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516202445/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press024.html |archivedate=16 May 2008 }} A summons was refused on 30 January 2007 due to lack of [[prima facie]] evidence that a crime had been committed, and the provisions of the [[Theatres Act 1968|1968 Theatres Act]], which enshrines the right of free expression in theatrical works.{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Press release: Summons refused in Springer blasphemy case |date=30 January 2007 |publisher=CV website |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press028.html |work= |pages= |accessdate=2008-10-02 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706125908/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press028.html |archivedate=6 July 2008 }} An appeal to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] was dismissed on 5 December 2007.{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Springer opera court fight fails | date=5 December 2007 | publisher=''BBC News'' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7128552.stm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language=}} On 5 March 2008 the House of Lords rejected the call to hear an appeal of the High Court's decision because "it did not raise an arguable point of law of general public importance".{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Springer case dismissed by Lords | date=5 March 2008 | publisher=''BBC News'' | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7279182.stm | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language=}} The offences of [[Blasphemy law in the United Kingdom|Blasphemy and Blasphemous Libel]] were abolished by the [[Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008]] with effect from 8 July 2008.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-05-23 |publisher=Ministry of Justice |title=Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 implementation |url=http://www.justice.gov.uk/publications/criminal-justice-act-implementation.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081105105702/http://www.justice.gov.uk/publications/criminal-justice-act-implementation.htm |archivedate=5 November 2008 }}{{cite web| accessdate = 2008-06-06|publisher=Institute for Humanist Studies|author=Ruth Geller|title=Goodbye to Blasphemy in Britain|url =http://humaniststudies.org/enews/?id=348&article=0 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080607204857/http://humaniststudies.org/enews/?id=348&article=0 |archivedate = 2008-06-07}} ===HPV Vaccine=== CV placed an advertisement in the [[New Statesman]] asserting that [[HPV vaccine]]s would make young people sterile. In January 2009, the Advertising Standards Authority ruled that the advertisement breached advertising regulations on accuracy.[http://thirdsector.co.uk/news/Article/877545/ASA-bans-misleading-Christian-Voice-advertisement/ ASA bans 'misleading' Christian Voice advertisement] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726121257/http://thirdsector.co.uk/news/Article/877545/ASA-bans-misleading-Christian-Voice-advertisement/ |date=26 July 2011 }}, Sarah Townsend, 2 February 2009, ''Third Sector Online'' Christian Voice had predicted the ruling and responded "requiring the substantiation of a future prediction in an opinion piece is preposterous and an infringement of freedom of speech."{{cite web |url=http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press120.html |title=ASA outlaws prediction and opinion |accessdate=June 1, 2016}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{dead link|date=August 2013}}. Christian Voice, 27 December 2008. ===Other=== In November 2008, following the failed private prosecution by Emily Mapfuwa over the display of a foot-high statue of Jesus with a [[phallus]] in the [[Baltic Centre for Contemporary Art]], [[Gateshead]], Stephen Green urged Christians to "create public disorder if [they] wish such a case to proceed in future", and stated that the artwork in question would "not survive being put on public display again."[http://www.northumberlandgazette.co.uk/latest-north-east-news/Christians-warn-of-backlash-ovr.4680606.jp Christians warn of backlash over Jesus statue case], [[Northumberland Gazette]], 12 November 2008 {{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}[http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/Press/press113.html CPS Wrecks Baltic Centre Case]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, press release, Christian Voice, 10 November 2008 {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} On 8 January 2009, Christian Voice complained to the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] about the [[Atheist Bus Campaign]]'s adverts on 800 buses across England, Scotland and Wales. CV objected to the slogan, "There's probably no God. Now stop worrying and enjoy your life."{{cite news | title=No God campaign draws complaint | date=8 January 2009 | publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7818980.stm | accessdate=2009-01-09}} On 21 January, the ASA ruled that the adverts were not in breach of its rules as the advert "was an expression of the advertiser’s opinion" and was incapable of substantiation. They also claimed that although the advert was contrary to many people's beliefs, it would not generate "serious or widespread offence".{{cite web |url=http://www.asa.org.uk/asa/news/news/2009/Atheist+bus+ad+campaign+not+in+breach+of+advertising+code.htm |title=Atheist bus ad campaign is not in breach of the Advertising Code |date=2009-01-21 |publisher=[[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|ASA]] |accessdate=2009-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318013752/http://asa.org.uk/asa/news/news/2009/Atheist%2Bbus%2Bad%2Bcampaign%2Bnot%2Bin%2Bbreach%2Bof%2Badvertising%2Bcode.htm |archivedate=18 March 2009 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7842769.stm|title=Atheist ads 'not breaking code'|date=2009-01-21|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2009-01-21}} In December 2010, when the BBC aired [[The Nativity (2010 TV series)|''The Nativity'']], described by the Church of England as a "gritty interpretation," Stephen Green objected to – in his eyes – the portrayal of Mary as a [[whore]]. He was documented in the press condemning the presentation saying "They wouldn’t mock the birth of [[Muhammad]], or anything to do with his life story. They wouldn’t ridicule Hinduism or Sikhism, but Christianity is their big target."{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/218290/Fury-over-BBC-s-Nativity-insult |title=Fury over BBC's Nativity insult |publisher=[[Daily Express]] |date=19 December 2010 |accessdate=2011-12-06}} ==Controversy== In February 2005, Christian Voice was reported to have caused the [[cancer]] charity, [[Maggie's Centres]], to decline a £3,000 donation from the proceeds of a special performance of ''[[Jerry Springer: The Opera]]''. The charity had been due to receive £10 per ticket for an afternoon gala but declined the donation after CV had threatened to picket their centres, which offer palliative care to cancer sufferers and their families.{{cite news | first=Colin | last=Blackstock | title=Militant Christians block donation to cancer charity | date=24 February 2005 | publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' | url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2005/feb/24/charities.charitymanagement | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language= | location=London}} In June 2005, Christian Voice's bankers, the [[The Co-operative Bank|Co-operative Bank]], instructed the group to close its account because the group's stance on homosexuality was in conflict with the bank's ethical policies of diversity.{{cite news | first= | last= | title=Co-op asks Christian Voice to quit | date=24 June 2005 | publisher=''The Guardian'' | url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2005/jun/24/ethicalmoney.religion | work= | pages= | accessdate=2008-10-02 | language= | location=London}} The ''[[Gay Times]]'' awarded an ethical corporate stance award to the Co-operative Bank in response to this move.Gay Times, February 2006. See [http://www.cfs.co.uk/servlet/Satellite?c=Page&cid=1169537495558&pagename=Corp%2FPage%2FtplCorp Awards] Co-operative Financial Services (retrieved 29 November 2007) In response to this, Christian Voice encouraged a boycott of the bank.[http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/coop.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516141316/http://www.christianvoice.org.uk/coop.html |date=16 May 2011 }} ==Media coverage== After the appearance of Green on ''[[Question Time (television)|Question Time]]'' in September 2005, the group was condemned by David Peel, then [[Moderator of the General Assembly]] of the [[United Reformed Church]]. Peel said:
It is a matter of some regret that ... the BBC should choose to undermine the reputation of Question Time by giving a platform to a small, self-selecting group distinguished by its claim to be a prophetic voice in this country ... Christian Voice has the right to express its extreme views, but it is as representative of Christian opinion in Britain as the [[Monster Raving Loony Party]] would be of mainstream political parties – and far less entertaining.
On 11 March 2008 Stephen Green was interviewed by openly gay celebrity [[Ian "H" Watkins]] for the [[BBC Wales]] programme ''Week In Week Out''{{cite web|title=Week In Week Out: The Only Gay In The Village|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00krpw4|publisher=[[BBC Wales]]|accessdate=4 January 2012}} where he told Watkins his lifestyle was ‘sinful’, and made him no better than serial killer [[Jeffrey Dahmer]].{{cite news|title=Gay singer tells of 'nightmare'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7289306.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=4 January 2012}} Green then appeared on the BBC Wales programme ''Dragon's Eye'' on 13 November 2008, after a campaign by CV caused the book chain [[Waterstone's]] to cancel a book-signing by Welsh poet, [[Patrick Jones]], described as "obscene and blasphemous" by Green.{{cite news | title=Christian group halts book launch | date=12 November 2008 | publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7725790.stm | accessdate=2008-11-14}} Jones instead read from his book at the [[Welsh Assembly]][http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/south-wales-news/blaenau-gwent/2008/12/18/headyheady-91466-22486648/ Headyheady], ''Gwent Gazette'', 18 December 2008 [[Philip Hensher]], a commentator for ''The Independent'' newspaper, describes Green as a comic character, and Christian Voice as an extremist group.{{Cite news | last= Hensher | first= | title= The religious find a friend in the law | newspaper= Independent | date= 12 Jan 2009 | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/philip-hensher/philip-hensher-the-religious-find-a-friend-in-the-law-1301588.html | location=London}} In ''The Guardian'' he has been described by [[George Monbiot]] as a "ranting [[homophobia|homophobe]]".{{Cite news | last= Monbiot | first= George | title= I'm pleased the case against this ranting homophobe was dropped | newspaper= Guardian | date= 3 Oct 2006 | url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/oct/03/comment.gayrights | location=London}} In May 2008, Green was featured in the British [[Channel 4]] [[current affairs (news format)|current affairs]] documentary series ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]] - In God's Name'' as a leader in the fundamentalist movement in the United Kingdom. This prompted [[Joel Edwards (UK)|Joel Edwards]], head of the [[Evangelical Alliance]], to write a public letter discounting Green's impact on Christianity, and calling him an extremist.[http://www.christiantoday.com/article/rev.joel.edwards.responds.to.dispatches.episode.in.gods.name/19105.htm Joel Edwards responds to Dispatches episode: 'In God's Name'], [[Christianity Today]], 28 May 2008: "Dispatches has a reputation for being selective and sensationalist, so perhaps I shouldn't have been shocked. But as someone at the heart of the Christian community, I simply didn't recognise the claims it made - echoed in the Sunday Telegraph - about a growing band of Christian fundamentalists trying to impose their will on society. Stephen Green, a key example given of this fundamentalist movement, is an extremist. The vast majority of Christians who watched last night would, like me, have recoiled in horror at some of the statements he made."{{Cite news|url=http://www.ekklesia.co.uk/node/7188|title=Evangelical leader unhappy with focus on 'eccentric fringe'|date=28 May 2008|publisher=[[Ekklesia (organisation)|Ekklesia]]|accessdate=29 August 2013}} ==See also== *[[Christian Concern]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4303965.stm A voice in the wilderness], BBC News, 28 February 2005 *http://www.mediawatchwatch.org.uk/?p=160 {{DEFAULTSORT:Christian Voice (Uk)}} [[Category:Christian organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Christian political organizations]] [[Category:Anti-abortion organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations that oppose same-sex marriage]]

{{Infobox official post | post = Consultation</>of the Republic of Texas | body = | native_name = | = File:Texas Declaration of Independencie.jpg | caption = Consultation delegates signed [[The Texas Declaration of Independence]] from [[Mexico]] at the [[Convention of 1836]] in [[Washington-on-the-Brazos]], [[Republic of Texas]] in from February-March 1836. | flag = | type = [[republic|Republican General Council]] | status = De-established | style = [[provisional government|Provisional war-time government]] | seat = [[Republic of Texas]] (multiple meeting locations) | appointer = 98 elected delegates | appointer_qualified = | termlength = Variable by election date | termlength_qualified = | constituting_instrument = [[Constitution of the Republic of Texas]] | precursor = [[Constitution of 1824|Mexican Constitution of 1824]] | formation = November 1835 | abolished = March 1836 | succession = Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and General Council | abbreviation = }}
The '''Consultation''' served as the provisional government of [[Mexican Texas]] from October 1835 to March 1836 during the [[Texas Revolution]]. Tensions rose in Texas during early 1835 as throughout Mexico [[federalism|federalists]] began to oppose the increasingly [[centralized government|centralist]] policies of the government. In the summer, [[Texians]] elected delegates to a political convention to be held in [[Gonzales, Texas|Gonzales]] in mid-October. Weeks before the convention and war began, settlers took up arms against Mexican soldiers at the [[Battle of Gonzales]]. The convention was postponed until November 1 after many of the delegates joined the newly organized volunteer [[Texan Army|Texian Army]] to initiate a [[siege of Bexar|siege of the Mexican garrison at San Antonio de Bexar]]. On November 3, a quorum was reached in San Antonio. Within days, the delegates passed a resolution to define why Texians were fighting. They expressed allegiance to the deposed [[Constitution of 1824]] and maintained their right to form an independent government while this document was not in effect. [[Henry Smith (Texas Governor)|Henry Smith]] was elected governor of the new provisional government and the remaining delegates formed a General Council. In the next weeks, the council authorized the creation of a new [[regular army]] to be commanded by [[Sam Houston]]. As Houston worked to establish an army independent from the existing volunteer army, the council repeatedly interfered in military matters.
After authorizing [[Matamoros Expedition|an expedition]] to take [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros, Mexico]], the council named several men, simultaneously, to organize and lead the assault, angry at the effect the expedition was having on existing Texian garrisons, Smith dissolved the council. Alleging that Smith did not have the authority to disband them, council members impeached him and lieutenant governor [[James W. Robinson (Texas and California)|James W. Robinson]] was named acting governor.
==Background== {{main article|Mexican Texas}} The [[Mexican War of Independence]] (1810-1821) severed Spain's control over much of [[New Spain|its North American territories]], including [[Spanish Texas|Texas]].<ref>Manchaca (2001), p. 161.</ref> The [[1824 Constitution of Mexico]] defined the new country as a [[federal republic]] with nineteen states and four territories. Due to limited population and extremely poor economies, the provinces of Texas and Coahuila were combined to become the state [[Coahuila y Tejas]].<ref name=manchaca162>Manchaca (2001), p. 162.</ref><ref name=vazquez51>Vazquez (1997), p. 51.</ref> In the hopes that an influx of settlers could control the Indian raids, the new government liberalized immigration policies for the region. Under the [[General Colonization Law]] people from the United States could, for the first time, legally settle in Texas.<ref name=manchaca164>Manchaca (2001), p. 164.</ref> Large tracts of land were granted to ''[[empresario]]s'', who were responsible for recruiting settlers and establishing communities in Texas. With one exception, the new colonies were settled by foreigners.<ref name=manchaca198and199>Manchaca (2001), pp. 198–9.</ref> ''[[Tejano]]s'', Texas residents of Mexican descent, were soon vastly outnumbered by [[Anglo#United States|Anglo]]s. By 1834, an estimated 30,000 Anglos lived in Coahuila y Tejas,<ref name=manchaca201>Manchaca (2001), p. 201.</ref> compared to only 7,800 Tejanos.<ref name=manchaca172>Manchaca (2001), p. 172.</ref> By 1833, Texas was divided into three political divisions: the Department of Béxar, the Department of [[Nacogdoches, Texas|Nacogdoches]], and the Department of the Brazos.<ref name=vazquez69>Vazquez (1997), p. 69.</ref>
[[File:Mexico 1835-1846 administrative map-en-2.svg|300px|thumb|left|A map of Mexico, 1835–1846, showing administrative divisions. The red areas show regions where separatist movements were active.]] {{History of Mexico |First Republic}} {{History of Texas}}
By late 1834, the Mexican government began transitioning from a [[federalism|federalist]] model to [[centralized government|centralism]].<ref name=davis112>Davis (2006), p. 112.</ref> Santa Anna overturned the 1824 Constitution, dismissed the state legislatures, and ordered all militias disbanded.<ref name=davis121>Davis (2006), p. 121.</ref><ref name=hardin6>Hardin (1994), p. 6.</ref> Federalists throughout Mexico were appalled. The governor of Coahuila y Tejas, [[Agustín Viesca]], refused to dissolve the legislature, instead ordering that the session reconvene in Béxar, further from the influence of the Mexican army.<ref name=davis122>Davis (2006), p. 122.</ref> Viesca was arrested before he reached Texas.<ref name=hardin23>Hardin (1994), p. 23.</ref> Citizens in the states of [[Oaxaca]] and [[Zacatecas]] took up arms.<ref name=davis121/>
Public opinion in Texas was divided.<ref name=lack24through6>Lack (1992), pp. 24–6.</ref> In June 1835, one group staged a minor revolt against customs duties in [[Anahuac, Texas|Anahuac]].<ref name=lack25>Lack (1992), p. 25.</ref> Resolutions by the city councils in [[Bastrop, Texas|Mina]], Gonzales, Goliad, and [[West Columbia, Texas|Columbia]] denounced their actions.<ref name=lack26through28/> Civic leaders in Mina were so disgusted they called for public meetings to determine whether settlers supported independence, a return to federalism, or the status quo. Although some leaders worried that Mexican officials would see this type of gathering as a step toward revolution, the ''[[ayuntamiento]]s'' of both Columbia and [[San Felipe, Texas|San Felipe]] quickly endorsed the suggestion. They hoped that a political convention would make it quite clear that the majority of [[Texian]]s did not support the radicals.<ref name=lack32>Lack (1992), p. 32.</ref> After the leaders of Columbia argued forcefully for the convention, the political chief of the [[Department (country subdivision)|department]] of the Brazos called for a meeting of representatives of municipalities in that department on August 1. Only four of the seven appointed delegates appeared. Discovering there was no official agenda, the four men returned home without actually doing anything.<ref name=lack31/>
As a response to the [[Anahuac disturbances]], the commander of the Mexican army in Texas, [[Domingo de Ugartechea]], requested reinforcements to help capture the dissidents.<ref name=lack26through28>Lack (1992), pp. 26–28.</ref> Small groups of soldiers began arriving in early August; in response, local municipalities formed Committees of Correspondence and Safety and unofficial militias.<ref name=lack31>Lack (1992), p. 31.</ref> On August 9, citizens at a public meeting in [[Brazoria, Texas|Brazoria]] again broached the idea of a larger political convention.<ref name=lack32and3>Lack (1992), pp. 32–33.</ref> Other communities debated whether to participate in such a convention, and whether its goals should be simply an exchange of opinions or to create an interim government.<ref name=davis132>Davis (2006), p. 132.</ref> The proposed political gathering, which became known as the Consultation, was endorsed by [[Stephen F. Austin]], the first ''empresario'' in Texas, on September 8, which solidified support throughout the Anglo colonies.<ref name=lack34>Lack (1992), p. 34.</ref> Austin became the ''de facto'' leader of the Consultation, making plans for the gathering, which would convene on October 15. He requested that each community send one delegate early, to form a Permanent Council to start gathering opinions.<ref name=davis136>Davis (2006), p. 136.</ref>
In the interim, hostilities between Mexican soldiers and Texas colonists increased, and in early October a group of [[Texian]]s attacked a Mexican army contingent which had been sent to retrieve a cannon that had previously been loaned to Gonzales. This small skirmish marked the official start of the [[Texas Revolution]]. Gonzales became a rallying point for Texas settlers who opposed the centralist policies, and men flocked to the town.<ref>Davis (2006), pp. 140–3.</ref> On October 11, the men formed themselves into a volunteer [[Texian Army]] and elected Austin as their commander.<ref name=winders55>Winders (2004), p. 55.</ref> Many of the Consultation delegates had also gathered in Gonzales, and rather than wait for the session to begin, they joined the army on a march against the Mexican garrison at Béxar.<ref name=winders69>Winders (2004), p. 69.</ref>
By October 16, only 31 delegates had arrived in San Felipe, short of a quorum.<ref name=lack41>Lack (1992), p. 41.</ref> Most expected the [[siege of Béxar]] to be over very quickly, so the Consultation was postponed until November 1. In the interim, this group of delegates granted power to the Permanent Council, which in practice included representation from only seven districts. The Permanent Council made weak attempts to govern the area, but primarily carried out Austin's orders. In its most controversial move, the council closed all land offices in the region on October 27, to prevent speculators from seizing land during the unrest.<ref name=lack42>Lack (1992), p. 42.</ref>
The [[siege of Béxar]] began in late October. Newly arrived immigrant [[Sam Houston]] traveled to Béxar to exhort the delegates to leave the siege and come to the Consultation. In a compromise, the officers voted to allow delegates who were members of the rank-and-file or were line officers to leave the siege, while those who were staff officers would remain to oversee military operations.<ref name=davis154and7>Davis (2006), pp. 154–157.</ref> [[William B. Travis]], [[William H. Wharton|William Wharton]], and [[Stephen F. Austin]] remained behind, while twenty delegates, including [[James Bowie]], accompanied Houston to San Felipe.<ref name=davis154and7/><ref name=todish24/>
==Delegates== Each municipality in Texas was encouraged to send five delegates to the convention. Some municipalities, including Nacogdoches, elected seven.<ref name=davis160>Davis (2006), p. 160.</ref> A total of 98 delegates were elected. These men were established citizens, with an average length of residence of seven years, with an average age of 38.<ref name=lack44/> Approximately one-third of the delegates were staunch supporters of the Constitution of 1824, another third strongly advocated independence, and the remainder were unaligned.<ref name=lack47>Lack (1992), p. 47.</ref>
Only 58 of these men attended. None of the delegates from the war areas - Béxar, Goliad, [[Refugio, Texas|Refugio]], [[Victoria, Texas|Victoria]], and [[San Patricio, Texas|San Patricio]] - appeared.<ref name=lack44/> This effectively ensured that there were no ''Tejano'' delegates that the Consultation.<ref name=davis164>Davis (2006), p. 164.</ref> Many delegates from the other regions of Texas remained in the army or stayed home to defend their families.<ref name=lack44>Lack (1992), p. 44.</ref> Because Austin and many of his Peace Party supporters were still with the army at Bexar, they were unable to provide as much influence to the gathering as expected.<ref name=winders69/>
An overwhelming percentage of the delegates who attended were men who had previous political experience. Twenty of them had been active in the Communities of Correspondence and Public Safety in their respective towns.<ref name=lack44/>
==Formation of government== A quorum finally formed on November 3,<ref name=winders69/> and delegates continued to arrive over the next few days.<ref name=davis166>Davis (2006), p. 166.</ref> Although Austin had endorsed [[Lorenzo de Zavala]] to preside over the gathering, delegates elected [[Branch Tanner Archer]] of [[Brazoria County, Texas|Brazoria]].<ref name=davis163>Davis (2006), p. 163.</ref> In a speech after his appointment, Archer urged his comrades "to divest yourselves of all party feelings, to discard every selfish motive, and look alone to the true interest of your country."<ref name=lack47/> Before the group could move towards official business, Houston rose to a make speech. He gave thanks to many for actions taken over the recent months. His eloquence was unimportant and unnecessary, except as a means for him to become better known to the other delegates.<ref name=davis165>Davis (2006), p. 165.</ref> For the remainder of the day, the delegates drafted rules of order. Similar to those used in the legislative bodies of the United States and Europe, the rules emphasized courtesy. In an unusual move, the rules prohibited delegates from abstaining from voting. As president, Archer was forbidden from voting except to break a tie.<ref name=davis165/>
The Consultation's main purpose was to decide the overall goals of the revolution. Members of the War Party advocated for complete independence from Mexico, while Peace Party representatives wished for Texas to remain part of Mexico, but only under the 1824 Constitution of Mexico. Although Austin was unable to attend, he did send a letter to the consultation, asking them to follow the Constitution of 1824 and to make it clear to Mexico that the hostilities were not an attempt for independence but instead a determination to fight for their rights as Mexican citizens.<ref name=winders69/>
On November 4, [[John Austin Wharton (1806–38)|John Wharton]] was named chair of a committee to determine the purpose of the war. After three full days of deliberation failed to produce a resolution, delegates began a full debate on the floor.<ref name=lack48>Lack (1992), p. 48.</ref> The turning point of the discussion came when Houston, who many believed to be a staunch member of the War Party, asked the fellow delegates to refrain from declaring independence. Such a declaration would likely cause many of the people who supported the Constitution of 1824 in other parts of Mexico to refrain from supporting the Texians.<ref name=todish24>Todish ''et al.'' (1998), p. 24.</ref> The Consultation compromised. On November 7, they released a resolution declaring that "The people of Texas, availing themselves of their natural rights, solemnly declare that they have taken up arms in defense of their rights and liberties which were threatened by the encroachments of military despots and in defense of the Republican principles of the federal constitution of Mexico of 1824."<ref name=todish24/> The resolution further specified that Texas reserved the right to create an independent government as long as Mexico was not governed by that [[1824 Constitution of Mexico|document]]. The members hoped that this wording would allow them to gain support from both federalists within Mexico and from the United States. The resolution passed 33–14.<ref name=winders69/>
In what historian [[William C. Davis (historian)|William C. Davis]] dubbed "the three shortest yet perhaps most significant resolutions in the document," the delegates agreed that Texas would pay for the army, would repay any goods purchased by its agents, and would give volunteers public lands. These were powers reserved for states, and under the Constitution of 1824 Texas was not a stand-alone state. With these words, delegates violated the very constitution they had sworn to uphold.<ref name=davis167>Davis (2006), p. 167.</ref> Davis asserts that this provision signified that the delegates fully intended for Texas to become an independent nation, eventually.<ref name=davis167/>
Fifty-seven delegates signed the resolution. de Zavala translated it into Spanish, and copies in both languages were ordered to be printed and distributed to residents.<ref name=davis167/> A committee was immediately established to design a provisional government, with [[Henry Smith (Texas Governor)|Henry Smith]] as chair. The committee's first proposal was a near-verbatim copy of the [[preamble to the United States Constitution]] and included a statement that Texas was now a "sovereign state".<ref name=lack49>Lack (1992), p. 49.</ref> Delegates voted against this draft and insisted that the committee membership be changed. All committee members who supported independence were removed from their positions, and the new committee began deliberations anew. On November 13, this group produced a document that won approval.<ref name=lack50>Lack (1992), p. 50.</ref>
The new government would consist of a chief executive and a General Council who would share powers. Under the assumption that these two branches would have full cooperation, there was no system of checks and balances.<ref name=lack50and1>Lack (1992), pp. 50–1.</ref> Believing there was no time to wait for general elections, the Consultation determined that the governor and lieutenant governor would be chosen by the delegates themselves, a practice somewhat common among states in the United States.<ref name=davis168>Davis (2006), p. 168.</ref> Although Austin was nominated, he lost to Smith 31–22.<ref name=winders72>Winders (2004), p. 72.</ref> [[James W. Robinson (Texas and California)|James Robinson]] was elected lieutenant governor.<ref name=lack50and1/> As lieutenant governor, Robinson would preside over the General Council, which would consist of one representative from each municipality.<ref name=davis169>Davis (2006), p. 169.</ref>
Three delegates-Austin, Archer, and Wharton-were appointed as agents to the United States to try to raise money and volunteers.<ref name=lack54>Lack (1992), p. 54.</ref> Austin immediately resigned his post as commander of the volunteers; the troops elected [[Edward Burleson]] as their new leader.<ref name=davis178>Davis (2006), p. 178.</ref> Houston was appointed to the Select Committee on Indian Affairs, as he had spent much of his career dealing with Indian nations. The Texians needed the support of the Indians (or at least their neutrality) to win their fight against Mexico.<ref name=todish24/>
The Consultation officially adjourned on November 15, leaving the new provisional government in charge.<ref name=lack52>Lack (1992), p. 52.</ref>
==General Council== [[File:Samuel houston.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Sam Houston]] was named commander of the new [[Texian Army]].]]
The soldiers currently fighting near Béxar were volunteers, who joined the army to accomplish a specific task and staunchly maintained their right to elect their own leaders. On November 13, the council officially established a [[regular army]]. Houston was appointed to command this new Provisional Army of Texas, subject to the orders of the governor. Houston was instructed to raise an army from scratch; because the volunteers had organized before the Consultation convened, they could not be forced to accept Houston as their commander.<ref name=winders70to72>Winders (2004), pp. 70–2.</ref> The new army should consist of 2,500 men, who would enlist for 2-year terms in exchange for land grants.<ref name=todish24/>
After consulting with some of the officers currently at the siege of Béxar, notably Travis and [[James W. Fannin]], the council chose to expand the army. On December 5 they created a Corps of Permanent Volunteers, which would have a shorter enlistment period and more autonomy.<ref name=winders76and77>Winders (2004), pp. 76–7.</ref> This move hindered Houston's efforts to fill his regular army; most citizens preferred to join the Permanent Volunteers.<ref name=winders76and78>Winders (2004), pp. 76, 78.</ref>
On December 11, the Mexican troops in Béxar surrendered and agreed to march south of the [[Rio Grande]]. With their departure, there was no longer an organized garrison of Mexican troops in Texas,<ref name=davis185>Davis (2006), p. 185.</ref> and many of the Texians believed that the war was over.<ref name=hardin91>Hardin (1994), p. 91.</ref> Burleson resigned his leadership of the army on December 15 and returned to his home. Many of the men did likewise, and [[Frank W. Johnson]] assumed command of the 400 soldiers who remained.<ref name=davis188>Davis (2006), p. 188.</ref>
The Mexican retreat gave the Council the time to formalize the government and begin planning for the future, without the threat of attack.<ref name=lack53>Lack (1992), p. 53.</ref> Little was accomplished.<ref name=lack54/> The new Texas government had no funds, so the military was granted the authority to impress any supplies that would be useful. This policy soon resulted in an almost universal hatred of the Council, as food and supplies became scarce, especially in the areas around Goliad and Béxar, where Texian troops were stationed.<ref name=lack54>Lack (1992), p. 54.</ref> The ''[[Telegraph and Texas Register]]'' noted that "some are not willing, under the present government, to do any duty...That our government is bad, all acknowledge, and no one will deny."<ref name=lack74>Lack (1992), p. 74.</ref>
Citing an aborted coup attempt on November 25, Smith proposed a bill making it treasonous to make threats against the provisional government. The Council, by now used to "the governor's addiction to exaggerated and inflammatory rhetoric", ignored him.<ref name=lack72>Lack (1992), p. 72.</ref> On December 19, a group of prominent citizens, led by [[Moseley Baker]], [[Wylie Martin]], and William Pettus, held a meeting in San Felipe to build support for dismantling the provisional government. They were concerned that the Council was moving too seriously towards independence instead of an adherence to the Constitution of 1824.<ref name=lack72/> Yet the Council had not gone far enough for some. Disillusionment with the interim government and an increased militancy among troops, whose ranks were now primarily composed of newly arrived volunteers from the United States, led to calls for a new convention. Brazoria passed a resolution asking for a convention to meet in March 1836 to declare independence. Soldiers in Goliad went a step further and drafted [[Goliad Declaration of Independence|a declaration of independence]] on December 22.<ref name=davis192>Davis (2006), p. 192.</ref> The Council passed a resolution to call the [[Convention of 1836]], to meet on March 1 in [[Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas|Washington-on-the-Brazos]].<ref name=lack76>Lack (1992), p. 76.</ref>
===Matamoros Expedition and collapse=== [[File:James W Robinson.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Lieutenant Governor [[James W. Robinson (Texas and California)|James W. Robinson]] became governor after the council impeached [[Henry Smith (Texas Governor)|Henry Smith]].]]
In mid-November Governor Viesca, who had been freed by sympathetic soldiers, reached [[Goliad, Texas|Goliad]]. The commander at Goliad, [[Philip Dimmitt]] welcomed Viesca but refused to recognize his authority as governor. This caused an uproar in the garrison; many supported the governor, while others believed that Texas should be an independent country and should therefore not recognize the Mexican governor.<ref name=lack191>Lack (1992), p. 191.</ref> Viesca traveled to San Felipe to meet with the General Council, who also refused to recognize his authority as governor. Viesca joined several others in advocating a plan to attack centralist troops in [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros]].<ref name=davis188>Davis (2006), p. 188.</ref> They hoped this [[Matamoros Expedition]] would inspire other federalist states to revolt and keep the bored Texian troops from deserting the army. Most importantly, it would move the war zone outside of Texas.<ref name=winders78>Winders (2004), p. 78.</ref> The governor initially supported the plan, and asked Houston to organize the expedition; Houston appointed [[James Bowie]] to lead the expedition, but Bowie did not receive his orders for several weeks.<ref name=winders79>Winders (2004), p. 79.</ref> The Council asked Burleson, the commander of the volunteers at Bexar, to lead the expedition. Burleson had already resigned, and his elected replacement, Johnson, instead received the message. While Johnson journeyed to San Felipe to meet with the Council, on December 30, Johnson's aide-de-camp, [[James Grant (Texas)|James Grant]] led 200 men from Béxar to travel to Goliad to prepare for the expedition.<ref name=winders80>Winders (2004), p. 80.</ref> Only 100 Texians remained at the [[Alamo Mission]] in Bexar, under the command of Lieutenant Colonel [[James C. Neill]].<ref name=winders80/> Neill was disgusted that Johnson had stripped the Alamo of almost all provisions and the majority of the men and sent a strong message to Houston asking for reinforcements and more supplies.<ref name=winders90and92/>
Although Bowie also appeared before the Council with his written orders from Houston to lead the Matamoros Expedition, on January 6 the Council authorized Johnson to lead the expedition. Johnson initially declined the commission, but changed his mind the following day. Without revoking Johnson's commission, the Council elected Fannin to lead the mission instead.<ref name=winders80/> Smith was incensed when he learned the Council had appointed their own commander for the expedition,<ref name=davis190>Davis (2006), p. 190.</ref> and he became even more angry when Houston forwarded the letter from Neill, with an added note that he believed the Johnson mission was illegal, as the council had not had a quorum when it was authorized.<ref name=winders90and92/> By now, both Smith and Houston had decided that the expedition had little chance of success.<ref name=davis191>Davis (2006), p. 191.</ref>
Smith denounced the expedition as idiocy and labelled its supporters either fools or traitors.<ref name=hardin109>Hardin (1994), p. 109.</ref> He then disbanded the council until March 1 unless they agreed to renounce the Matamoros Expedition. The council determined that Smith had no authority to dismiss them.<ref name=winders90and92>Winders (2004), pp. 90, 92.</ref> They soon impeached Smith and named the lieutenant governor, Robinson, Acting Governor. The documents forming the provisional government, however, did not grant the council the authority to impeach the governor.<ref name=hardin109/>
On January 12, Smith wrote a conciliatory letter to the council: "I admit that I [used] language beyond the rules of decorum", and declared that if the council would admit that their actions regarding the Matamoros Expedition were wrong he would reinstate them so that "the two branches [would] again harmonize to the promotion of the true interests of the country".<ref name=winders92>quoted in Winders (2004), p. 92.</ref> Weary of the infighting and unsure who was actually in charge, Council members slowly stopped appearing. In the hopes of salvaging a government, Robinson appointed four members to an Advisory Committee. Soon, this dwindled to only two members. The interim government was essentially over by the end of January.<ref name=lack73>Lack (1992), p. 73.</ref>

Keeney''' (born July 2, 1937) is an American scientist in [[soil science]] and water chemistry. He was the first director of the Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture in [[Ames, Iowa]]. ==Early life and education== Keeney grew up on his family's dairy farm near [[Runnells, Iowa]] not far from Des Moines.{{cite web|title=Dennis Keeney|url=http://iatp.org/about/staff/dennis-keeney|publisher=Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy|accessdate=3 March 2015|date=n.d.}}{{cite web|author1=Kate Fried|title=Food for Thought With Dr. Dennis Keeney|url=http://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/blogs/food-for-thought-with-dr-dennis-keeney/|publisher=Food & Water Watch|accessdate=2 March 2015|location=Washington DC|format=Blog|date=February 20, 2015}} He graduated from [[Iowa State University]] (ISU) with a B.S. in [[agronomy]]. He studied [[soil science]] at [[University of Wisconsin]] and obtained an M.S., followed by a Ph.D. in agronomy and biochemistry from Iowa State University. ==Career== Keeney became a professor of agronomy, and stayed on as faculty member in soils and water chemistry for more than 20 years.{{cite news|author1=Anthony Capps|title=- Memoir looks at life of first director of the Leopold Center|url=http://amestrib.com/news/memoir-looks-life-first-director-leopold-center#sthash.kPNUtuIX.dpuf|accessdate=2 March 2015|work=Ames Tribune|date=February 6, 2015}} In 1987, the Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture was established at ISU, and in 1988 he became its first director. The Leopold Center developed research studies and teaching about the environmental impacts of farming, [[sustainable agriculture]], preservation of natural resources, including soil and water quality, and [[rural community development]]. Keeney defined sustainable agriculture as
"It means using the resources we have wisely. Probably number one to conserve the soil resource, the water resource, and the land resource. It's a Leopold concept really, because Leopold talked about land as the water, the air, the soil, and the animals living on it."
Already in 1988 Keeney examined the [[Energy balance (energy economics)|energy balance]] of [[ethanol fuel]] as a "renewable" fuel and concluded, that more energy was required to produce ethanol than was retrieved from it then. Keeney retired from the Leopold Center in 1999. He was suucceeded by Fred Kirschenmann.{{cite web|title=1987-2012| url=http://www.leopold.iastate.edu/25year|publisher=Leopold Center for Sustainable Agriculture|accessdate=3 March 2015|date=2012}} With the [[corn ethanol]] industry rapidly expanding between 2000 and 2005, in what Keeney called "...an "irrational exuberance" trip with biofuels" he was one of few Iowa scientists looking at water consumption.Dennis Keeney and Mark Muller [http://iatp.org/documents/water-use-by-ethanol-plants-potential-challenges Water Use by Ethanol Plants: Potential Challenges] October 24, 2006, IATP. In 2009, Keeney published his latest peer-reviewed paper on the "Environmental, social, economic, and food issues brought on by the rapidly expanding ethanol-from-corn industry in the United States".Keeney D [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=dennis+Keeney Ethanol USA.] Environmental Science & Technology. 2009 Jan 1;43(1):8-11.{{PMID|19209577}} {{As of|2014}} he has continued to publicly question its benefits.{{cite news|author1=Dennis Keeney|title=Dennis Keeney: The other side of corn-based ethanol|url= http://amestrib.com/opinion/dennis-keeney-other-side-corn-based-ethanol#sthash.byn8rWX8.dpuf|accessdate=3 March 2015|work=Ames Tribune|date=30 April 2014}} He was president of the [[Soil Science Society of America]] and the [[American Society of Agronomy]].{{cite web|author1=Levins Publishing|title=The Keeney Place: A Life in the Heartland|url=http://levinspublishing.com/the-keeney-place/#sthash.hrNE0swM.dpuf|publisher=Levins Publishing|accessdate=2 March 2015|date=n.d.}} {{As of|2015}} he consults as a Senior Fellow for the [[Institute for Agriculture and Trade Policy]] in Minneapolis and the Department of Soil, Air and Water at the [[University of Minnesota]]. He is a visiting scholar for the [[Center for a Livable Future]], Johns Hopkins University.{{cite web|title=Dennis Keeney Distinguished Lecture Series| url=http://www.leopold.iastate.edu/news/calendar/keeney#sthash.hwZRASHV.dpuf|publisher=Iowa State University|author=College of Agriculture and Life Sciences|accessdate=2 March 2015|date=n.d.}} In February 2015 his memoir “The Keeney Place: A Life in the Heartland” was published after nine years of work. The book title refers to the fact that per Keeney "the farm you grew up on, at least for a couple of generations, was named after the family that lived there. It became a sense of place that we really miss, because now agriculture is large corporate farms that have no sense of place. It’s a way of life that is largely gone." ==Selected publications== Keeney has published over 140 peer reviewed papers on soil and water quality research. *Dennis Keeney “The Keeney Place: A Life in the Heartland”, Levins Publishing. 110 pages. Website: thekeeneyplace.com *[http://iatp.org/documents/nitrogen-and-the-mississippi Nitrogen and the Mississippi] September 11, 2000, IATP *[http://iatp.org/documents/nitrogen-and-the-upper-mississippi-river Nitrogen and the Upper Mississippi River] March 17, 2002, IATP *[http://iatp.org/documents/testimony-to-the-us-commission-on-ocean-policy-0 Testimony to the US Commission on Ocean Policy], September 30, 2002 *[http://iatp.org/documents/new-road-the-0 The New Road] April 15, 2003 *[http://iatp.org/documents/ipm-presentation-0 Genetically Modified Crops and Integrated Pest Management adoption] April 15, 2003 *[http://iatp.org/documents/shallow-water Shallow Water] October 12, 2003 *[http://iatp.org/documents/performance-based-approach-to-control-of-agricultural-non-point-source-pollution-0 Performance Based Approach to Control of Agricultural Non Point Source Pollution] October 20, 2003 *[http://iatp.org/documents/our-fragile-food-supply Our fragile food supply] September 2, 2004 *[http://iatp.org/documents/reducing-nutrients-in-the-mississippi-river-and-the-gulf-of-mexico Reducing Nutrients in the Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico] December 14, 2006 *[http://iatp.org/documents/biofuel-and-global-biodiversity Biofuel and Global Biodiversity] May 5, 2008 *[http://iatp.org/documents/agriculture-sustainability Agriculture Sustainability] February 28, 2010 *[http://iatp.org/documents/colonialism-is-not-dead Colonialism is not dead] March 21, 2010 *[http://iatp.org/blog/201208/drought-in-my-life Drought in my life] August 6, 2012 *[http://iatp.org/blog/201208/resiliency-agriculture-and-the-2012-drought Resiliency, agriculture and the 2012 drought] August 14, 2012 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *Dennis Keeney: Ethanol's Power Politics; {{For|the racehorse|Deputy Minister (horse)}} '''Deputy minister''' is a title borne by politicians or officials in certain countries governed under a [[parliamentary system]]. In some countries a "Deputy minister" is a junior [[Minister (government)|minister]], who is assigned to assist a specific [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] minister.
*'''Bangladesh:''' A Deputy minister is junior to a Minister of a Department of State (portfolio minister) and of similar standing to a Parliamentary Secretary.<ref name="National Web Portal of Bangladesh">{{cite web|title=Hon'ble Deputy Ministers|url=http://cabinet.portal.gov.bd/site/page/28b4f09d-8797-4591-9cd6-46b93a58f674/%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%80%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%AA-%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%A8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%97%E0%A6%A3||accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> *'''Canada:''' The [[Deputy minister (Canada)|Deputy minister]] is the senior [[civil servant]] in a government department. He or she takes political direction from an appointed [[minister of the Crown]].<ref>Jackson, Robert J. and Doreen Jackson. ''Politics in Canada: Culture, Institutions, Behavior and Public Policy''. 6th ed. (Toronto: Prentice Hall, 2006). p355.</ref> *'''Netherlands:''' A [[State Secretary (Netherlands)|State Secretary]] is the title of a junior member of the [[Cabinet of the Netherlands]]. *'''Tanzania:''' The [[Deputy Ministers of Tanzania|Deputy ministers]] are junior ministers, and are usually not members of the government's cabinet
